abstract: The oil company’s new chief executive has to repair its image with investors.
snippet: The oil company’s new chief executive has to repair its image with investors.
lead_paragraph: BP is sounding decisive and radical. The beleaguered British oil major is expanding its existing asset disposal program to $30 billion and looking to cut debt after announcing a $32 billion charge on its Gulf of Mexico oil spill in Tuesday’s earnings report. And Tony Hayward is to step down as chief executive. But for Mr. Hayward’s American successor, Robert Dudley, one big challenge is to turn this into a convincing story for the company’s stock.

headline.print_headline: Eyes on the Spill And the Investors

byline.original: By FIONA MAHARG-BRAVO and MARTIN HUTCHINSON
